A lot of those quote,

nuances and differences

And so for them, it's really,

because at the end of the

So from the cloud perspective, Sameer,
back to you.
I heard Nati mention edge,
and edge can be a very ambiguous term.

Talk to me about how we think
about the edge here at AWS.

So one of our VPs, Bill Vass,
defines this really well.
He basically says the edge
is where you want to act on the data.
It is really a continuum.
So at AWS, we have
a wide continuum of edge

I mean running on
microprocessors with IoT Core
because we act on the data

on the microprocessor
itself with IoT Core, right?
On the other end of the spectrum,
we have Local Zones,
or even regions, right?
Because that's where the data lives.
That is the edge by definition.

And IoT Core through to
devices such as Monitron,

which do manufacturing
monitoring as the name suggests,
we have a lot of robotics applications,
RoboMaker, for example.

We have this for disconnected
mode of operations.
We have the Snow Family,

which operates in rugged
environments like battlefields

and disconnected environments
like ships at sea and so on.
And then moving on up,

we have various different
form factors of Outposts,

which is essentially the same
direct-level infrastructure

or server-level infrastructure
we use in our data centers.

But that can then move
into an on-prem environment
and provide the cloud, not just compute,
but the whole power of the cloud
within an on-premise environment.

And some people may choose to
run their edge applications
on the Local Zones,

which are metro area deployments
and data centers for us.
So, you know, just to expand on that,

for us the edge solves
three problems, right?
One is the law of economics.
You do not really want to transport
these terabytes and petabytes of data

to a central location every
time you want to act on it.
The second is the law of the land

where we actually have
a lot of regulations
coming in on data residency,
where certain data can live,

where certain data can
be visualized and so on.
And the third one is the law of physics,

which is, there are real
time applications now,

in safety and in automotive
vehicles and so on,

where you need that five
millisecond, 10 millisecond
or even better latency.

So our edge follows one
of those three laws.
That's the way we look at it.
And so you talked about this,
all of these sets of services
that are highly geo-distributed,

that often have very low
latency requirements.
Seems to me that DevOps and automation,

all the topics, Nati,
that you're referring to,
are an absolute must.
Maybe starting with you Max,
how important is DevOps methodology
to these types of use cases?

And then Nati, what types
of services are you building
or were you building at Cloudify

to help deliver on what
customers were asking for?
Yep. It's extremely important, right?
If you look at,

from virtualizations
moving to cloud native,
DevOps is part of it, right?
It's part of it to enable the transition

of the platform's features, right?

Say today, within the world
of the largest install base
or the server base on Intel,

we do have a set of the
platform features, right,
that customer they consume over the years.

They don't have the luxury
to just move it overnight,
just overnight.
It wouldn't happen.
So it need times.
And it need times to learn the skillset,
it need times to plan the migration.
So that DevOps will come into the place

"When do I migrate,

when do I push a push

And to maintain the consistency as well
in terms of the features they consume.

And that's where Cloudify

to make sure that the
transition will happen

and glue us together between
AWS and Intel, right?

The platform consistency
will just go across,
from gen to gen migration.
And it's going to be a journey.
It going to be a journey,
say from virtualization to cloud native,
DevOps plays such a critical role, right?
It's a tool to join it all together.
Yeah,

so I'll try to take the
developer perspective into that.

edge as another compute node,

potentially as if it was
just a simple extension
of the cloud,
I would say in a very abstract way.

We all know that the physics are different

is really to abstract a

in some cases it's not even

There is obviously much more
regulation and security things
that needs to be done
but a lot of that needs to be plumbing

from a developer perspective
that is obstructed.
So first challenge for us
is really to look at those differences

and try to see, how do we
hide them from a developer?
I'll give you one challenge
to make it something more down to earth.
In a regular data center,
I would probably deploy an application
on a central EKS cluster
and that will be my domain, my cluster,

maybe another site for disaster
recovery of availability.
In an edge, most likely,
and there's a production use case

that we're running right
now, it's 30,000 sites.

30,000 Kubernetes clusters all
running the same application.

So from a developer perspective,
it's one application
but it's located in 30,000 sites.
Now, how do you ensure

that such an application actually
go to those 30,000 sites?
What happened if it got to 20,000,
sorry, 29,000 sites,

but the rest of the
9,000 wasn't successful?
How do you know which one of them failed
and how do you resume from that failures?
How do you roll back if that case happens?
How do you deal with multi-tenancy
in that type of environment,
where different customers have access
to those type of environments?
There is a lot of those challenges
that if you don't abstract them,

it's becoming a very,
very complex environment,
and there is no way a developer

can even write a continuous
update into this.
The last thing that I will mention,
not to take too much time,

is the realization that
system always drifts,
especially at scale.

When you're, again, in
a central data center,
that drift can be manageable.

When we have 30,000 sites
running in different versions,

you don't really upgrade
them at the same time.

You don't get them even
from the same vendor
or the same software.
So how do you deal with such a problem

without exposing that
complexity to the developers?

Because again, if you
expose it to the developers,
it's becoming nightmare.
And that's really what we're trying to do.

Really trying to take a
lot of those challenges

and saying, okay, developer
doesn't have to know about that,
how do we hide it, how do we obstruct it?
And we bring a lot of that complexity
or knowledge or smartness or whatever

into the orchestrator itself
rather than developer itself.
That's really in a nutshell.

Kubernetes clusters manually,
